User-Agent:       Opera/9.80 (Windows NT 5.1; U; en) Presto/2.8.131 Version/11.10
Build Identifier: 1.0b4pre

 

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Configure an alarm
2. Start a fullscreen application (e.g. a game)
3. Wait for the alarm to go off

Actual Results:  
Fullscreen application is interrupted and the alarm gets focussed.

Expected Results:  
Alarms should not disturb fullscreen applications or at least they should do this only when configured to do so.

We don't really have much choice here. The Mozilla Platform gives us methods to make the alarm window pop up in front of other windows. So its either always or never, we can't decide for full screen app or not.

I personally think this would better be fixed by having the mozilla platform give us a way to detect this case, but its probably possible to do this on our own. Given the high amount of code that needs to be written to achieve this (platform dependent, etc), this won't be a priority. Nevertheless confirming this bug.

comments.text:
The stealing of focus happens regardless of the other running programs being full-screen or not. When it does that, it steals the focus of the keyboard and the mouse, interrupting anything the user had been doing. This is quite destructive to the user's workflow, but may be acceptable once in the spirit of letting the user know of an upcoming event. Though, still, the normal thing would be being able to choose to not have the focus stolen at all. The reminder window flashing like crazy in the taskbar is already visible enough, not to mention if you also have a notification sound set.

The greater problem is that it doesn't happen only once.

If you have calendars that are synced from an online server (for example CalDAV), this thing happens _every_single_time_ the calendar from which the reminder originates from is refreshed. (About this, see https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=770012 .) If your calendar is refreshing every 5 minutes, and you don't dismiss or snooze all reminders right away, it does this every 5 minutes. If you close the reminder window, 5 minutes later it will come back again and steal focus. If you just click back into the window you were previously working in to regain focus, the reminder window will come back again and steal focus. If you minimize the reminder window, then it's a bit better, because it won't steal the focus again, but it will keep reminding you every 5 minutes by flashing in the taskbar (and playing the notification sound if you have one).

This has been so annoying and distracting for me that words can barely convey the frustration I've been going through. I kindly ask you, please, fix this behavior and/or give the user some options, at least in about:config, to be able to manipulate this behavior. Thank you.

comments.raw_text:
This is a serious issue with Lightning (Thunderbird Calendar).  As has been described, the real crux of the issue is that the reminders steal focus (and mouse/keyboard input) from the user with no warning.  This causes whatever the user was typing or possibly clicking to be ingested by the reminder window, often before the user is even aware that something has popped up.  In my opinion this issue is a foolish windows design flaw that shows up in a lot of applications, even the operating system itself.  When I say "widows" I may mean the Redmond OS but I also mean other window based multitask systems such as the Cupertino OS or linux or whatever.  There have been improvements over the years, with "toast" concepts introduced, as well as the native notifications.  In short, I understand the history of this, but it should have been fixed universally 30 years ago, which is as long as I've been dealing with this foolishness.  I can't tell you how many times I've had a "flash" notification from an OS or some app only to have my next keypress or mouse click accept SOMETHING on that dialog.  I don't know what it said, I don't know what I pressed, I have no idea what the ramifications are.  I just know it stole focus while I was writing something and then happened to press a space bar or enter key, or maybe it jumped up right under where I was about to click something else with my mouse, and BOOM, something was DECIDED.  It's crazy.  DESIGN FLAW.  Long overdue to be fixed.  Let's fix it in Lightning.  I use Lightning constantly and power multiple calendars with it, integrated with my work and family life, sharing with my wife on google calendars and her work's imposed MS calendar.  It works great for the most part and my family would struggle without the help of multiple shared calendars.  This issue shows up in Lightning more than anything else because I get multiple popups per hour, and the laws of statistics dictate some % of the time it's going to get interacted with before I even realize it has popped up.  I would say it happens about once every two weeks.

There are multiple related bugs and complaints that are "different" but all are part of making Thunderbird/Lightning notifications WORK for everyone.  The entire functionality of alerts needs to be rethought and reworked.  Here are a few others, I'm sure the list is non-exhaustive.

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=433531
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1164412
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1073758

While one might say various bugs are dupes, I would instead say they are different but very related, and it would be wise to consider them in tandem.  I also would say that this bug gets closest to the heart of the biggest issue in my mind:  Stealing focus and actually DOING STUFF because the user was typing or clicking on something else but the dialog jumps up in the middle and thinks the user gave it input, even though the user did not even have a chance to see the dialog yet.

IMO the way forward should include:
* No popup or "Alert" should steal keyboard focus, ever.  Any window popping up and stealing focus is a DESIGN ERROR.
  -- it SHOULD generally be VISIBLE as a top level window, but like down in the corner (an alert you never see is pointless)
 --  or at minimum for emails and appointments a system-tray icon option showing an "alerted" state should be visible and active such as a pulse and/or a count
 -- it should have a timer that disallows mouse interaction for a period (so a user can't accidentally click on it before knowing what they clicked) (I would suggest about 1 second, let's call this the "DEADZONE" period)
 -- a "toast" style notification should automatically disappear (fade/slide) after about 3-5 seconds.
 -- clicking a popup "toast" (with a mouse or touch action, AFTER the DEADZONE but before it is gone) or tray icon should then either:
           A) launch a new interactive window (perhaps the current one is fine, since the user would have requested it by that point)
           B) Cause the "toast" to be persistent and interactive, obtaining keyboard focus
* Allow to switch between System Notification (whatever the host OS supports, if any) and app-native "Toast" -- some don't like the OS version, I personally agree with that on some systems
* Allow to configure some options for how much detail and when it shows
  -- allow to show minimal detail in any notification (due to privacy issues, when screencasting for example)
       Just say "You have a reminder..." or something minimal like that
  -- allow to respect "focus" settings, like 
       --don't popup at all ever (no toast, no OS notification popup), use only a system tray icon instead  (checkbox)
       --don't popup at all when any other window is maximized (checkbox)
       --don't popup at all when "focus mode" is engaged by the OS (if supported) (checkbox)

At minimum, switching to a toast style (OS native or app-native, either one or both) and supporting a "minimal detail" option would be a HUGE step in the right direction, other stuff could be added incrementally.
Finally I will note, some of these ideas may be hard to implement on some OS's that's fine.  Some of these things may already exist, for example I think Thunderbird itself does handle much of this, but currently LIGHTNING does not and it needs to.

I have not written code for any Mozilla project but I likely could get it done myself given enough time.  I may consider working on this type of fix, but I would want direction on if my work would be accepted.  Although I do have access to windows, linux, and Mac, I may lack system integration knowledge to do this well on all of them.  I may alternatively consider giving direct funds to help a Mozilla team expert take care of it, depending on what amount is "motivating".   I say it is just a HORRIBLE bug to "do stuff" the user does not even know is being done and it needs to be fixed as a major flaw in any app or system that still does this.

I agree 150% with everything that JC said. Stealing focus is an absolute no-no in a correctly designed application which passed a UCD review. I have seen pop-ups that do NOT steal the focus, so it is doable. I don't remember which app, nor which OS (Windows of macOS).

I would also like to note that the popping up seems to get even worse if you are in the calendar, such as creating a new event for example. Given that I have 5 calendars from 5 Google accounts (with various sync intervals), I don't understand why refreshing a calendar should be linked in any way to how often the pop-up occurs, which is sometimes every minute (insanely infuriating).

Something absolutely needs to be done about this.

What (financial) incentive do the developers need to percolate this to the top of their stack? This is not a new bug by any stretch of the imagination. It was open 10 years ago, and has not been addressed. TEN YEARS??????? Gee wiz.

Current versions of Outlook is an example you need.  I have tens of reminders everyday from my agenda but its reminder window just makes a "peep" sound and turns the color of the icon on the taskbar.  That's all!  Very user-friendly.

comments.text:
Another year has passed since my last comment (Jan 9, 2021) and Teng-Fong's (Jan 15, 2021) reply to my comment. And nothing that I am aware of has happened (not a single comment anyhow). When I was still on TB78, I had read about the new features that TB91 was supposed to bring. One of them was "less aggressive" (or similar wording) reminder pop-ups. It was so exciting to read that.

So when TB91 came out, I upgraded. It was not less aggressive at all, it actually got worse in my opinion, but that just could be my growing frustration. I have 10 Google calendars in TB, so it is extremely rare to have all reminders dismissed at any given time, because many of my calendar events are reminders for things I need to do, others are appointments. By the time I finish something and I am able to dismiss the particular reminder, another one has arrived. So the problem of aggravating pop-ups is a constant occurrence for me.

So I am repeating my offer to contribute financially (I can't contribute code, sorry, my coding days are long gone), since I did not get a response on that a year ago. What would it take for this bug to percolate to the top of the stack? The problem is ELEVEN YEARS OLD, for heaven sake, and enough people are affected by it.

Thanks.

Pierre
